section.title: Restore your data

warning.para: Although OmegaT is a robust application, you should take precautions to guard against data loss when using it, just as with any other application.

Make regular and automatic backups of all your projects and files and regularly practice "emergency" measures, like restoring translations from a project, to make sure you won't lose too much time the day you need to use those skills.

section.para: When you translate the documents in a project, OmegaT stores all your progress in the translation memory file located in the folder. That file is saved at regular intervals, and you can also use to make sure important data in the meanwhile.

In that folder, OmegaT also automatically creates backup files of that translation memory every time you open or reload a project. OmegaT stores up to 10 backup files there with names like project_save.tmx.YYYYMMDDhhmm.bak where the final part is the time stamp indicating when the file was created: YYYY represents the 4-digit year, MM the month, DD the day of the month, and hh and mm indicate the hours and minutes.

The first backup is project_save.tmx.bak, which is a copy of project_save.tmx created when the project was opened. Then come the incremental backup files that are created as your translation progresses. project_save.tmx is always the file with the most recent data.
If you believe that you have lost translation data, follow the steps below to restore the project to the most recent backup memory, which is usually less than ten minutes old or so.

listitem.para: Rename the current project_save.tmx file (to project_save.tmx.tmp, for example).
Select the backup translation memory most likely to contain the data you are looking for.
Make regular copies of the file /omegat/project_save.tmx to a backup media, such as a USB key or an external hard drive, or to a cloud service.
While you are still familiarizing yourself with OmegaT, create translated files at regular intervals to make sure they contain the latest version of your translation.

Be very cautious about making changes to the files in the folder, or to the segmentation rules, partway through a project. Modifying either source files or the segmentation rules after you have started your translation could result in OmegaT becoming unable to find a segment that you have already translated.

Consult the Instant Start Guide and other sections of this manual to get started. Should you run into problems, post a message in the OmegaT user group. Do not hesitate to post in the language you are most comfortable using.
